title: Winch Driver and Remote Controller
text: A live winch demo is located at the bottom of the page

title: Winch Driver and Remote Controller
text:
Impact Overview
During my last week at AHI I was asked to design a remote control for the winch I had previously written the driver for. This request came from the mechanical team and led to a rushed but fruitful collaobrtion during my last days at the company. The winch was replacing a manual tether-looping process with a fully automated winch system. This evolution was critical for the company since it allowed for controlled deployment and recovery of the ROV at precise distances and speeds. The ROV’s primary purposed was the inspection and repair of subsea infrastrcuture making everything surrounding it a mission critical product for the company. By developing the firmware and control logic for the winch I enabled the team to rapidly test and iterate on the ROV housing designs. In order to determine the features on the controller I worked closely with the mechanical team and testing team to align hardware features with their deliverables.

title: Winch Driver and Remote Controller
text:
What I owned



High-Frequency Stepper Driver Developed a custom driver using the STM32 HSE clock to generate high-precision signals, mimicking PWM for smooth stepper motor actuation.


Precision Motor Control Implemented closed-loop control algorithms to manage winch speed and torque during payload deployment.




Safety State Machines Designed firmware logic to detect stall conditions or current spikes, preventing hardware damage during retraction.


Feature design Worked with mechanical team to design the features of the remote based on product deliverables and test items.




Hardware Integration & Housing Designed and executed the electrical wiring architecture and informed development of the protective housing unit for the electronics.

title: Winch Driver and Remote Controller
text:
Remote Functions













Dynamic Velocity Scaling Built “Faster” and “Slower” functions that live-updated the stepper pulse frequency for variable-speed recovery and deployment.


Manual Jogging Developed a “Jog” mode for fine-tuned positioning, allowing operators to hold and release the jog button to make incremental adjustments to the ROV’s depth.




Directional Switching Programmed the logic to toggle motor polarity, enabling seamless transitions between deployment and recollection of the ROV.


Start/Stop Implemented interrupt-driven logic to safely initialize or halt winch operations for a controlled ROV deployment.

title: Winch Driver and Remote Controller
text: Live Winch Demo

title: Prime Air Delivery Drone
text:
During takeoff in urban environments, Prime Air couldn’t accurately measure the location and orientation of its delivery drones (pictured below) due to electromagnetic interference from the surrounding buildings. I was on a team of six engineers tasked with solving these EMI-related localization failures. While researching non-GPS localization methods, I found AprilTags and introduced them to my team as a possible solution. We ended up going forward with them, and I led the sub-team developing them into our final solution.
During my time with Amazon Prime Air, I also worked on integrating sensors such as Lidar and cameras into the system. For the lidar, I worked with the subteam handling RFID sensors to integrate and tune sensor fusion pipelines combining RFID and LiDAR to improve robustness in state estimation. For the camera, I developed ROS nodes to enable real-time communication between perception systems and the flight controller.
The results of my work led to a trade study for Prime Air in which I wrote sections evaluating LiDAR- and vision-based localization approaches for aerial robotics. My work helped inform future navigation strategies for autonomous delivery platforms across the Prime Air platform.








Picture of Mk-37 Drone In Seattle Warehouse

title: Prime Air Delivery Drone
text:
During takeoff in urban environments, Prime Air couldn’t accurately measure the location and orientation of its delivery drones (pictured below) due to electromagnetic interference from the surrounding buildings. I was on a team of six engineers tasked with solving these EMI-related localization failures. While researching non-GPS localization methods, I found AprilTags and introduced them to my team as a possible solution. We ended up going forward with them, and I led the sub-team developing them into our final solution.
During my time with Amazon Prime Air, I also worked on integrating sensors such as Lidar and cameras into the system. For the lidar, I worked with the subteam handling RFID sensors to integrate and tune sensor fusion pipelines combining RFID and LiDAR to improve robustness in state estimation. For the camera, I developed ROS nodes to enable real-time communication between perception systems and the flight controller.
The results of my work led to a trade study for Prime Air in which I wrote sections evaluating LiDAR- and vision-based localization approaches for aerial robotics. My work helped inform future navigation strategies for autonomous delivery platforms across the Prime Air platform.








Picture of Mk-37 Drone In Seattle Warehouse

title: Prime Air Delivery Drone
text:
What I Owned



Vision-Based Localization Resolved EMI-related takeoff failures by designing an AprilTag system for high-accuracy pose estimation.


Multi-Modal Sensor Fusion Integrated and tuned RFID and LiDAR data streams to ensure robust state estimation in complex environments.




GPS-Denied Navigation Researched and prototyped novel navigation techniques for Mk-30 delivery drone autonomy.


Real-Time ROS Integration Developed custom ROS nodes to bridge communication between perception systems and flight control hardware.












Example of AprilTag identification with optical sensor


The team chose me to lead the visual sensor subteam. This decision was based on both my experience with programming and cameras, as well as my familiarity with using AprilTags (shown above) for pose estimation. The idea I pitched for the AprilTags is that when a camera is trained on them, depending on the size and orientation of the markers on the tag, it’s possible to calculate the drone’s position relative to the tag. Since the AprilTags location would be static and known, calculating where the drone was in space would be trivial. Founded on that idea, my subteam designed a vision-based AprilTag pose estimation system using onboard cameras, enabling reliable initialization in challenging electromagnetic environments.

title: Fused Multiply Accumulator Unit
text:
I designed and implemented a custom multicycle processor module in SystemVerilog capable of performing fused multiply-add operations on 16-bit half-precision floating-point numbers. I designed the unit in SystemVerilog, synthesized my iterations using Verilator. For testing, I wrote unit tests and analyzed register and variable signals over time. I also evaluated the hardware performance of FMA by generating area and timing reports, identifying the critical path, and computing the area–delay product to balance speed and efficiency.
This project challenged me to integrate multiple hardware concepts, including exponent alignment, mantissa normalization, and handling corner cases for addition and subtraction with differing exponents. I built supporting modules such as unpacking, product rounding, and shift/leading-zero detection logic, which all come together to execute floating-point arithmetic at the hardware level. By working through the details of rounding, overflow, and subtraction edge cases, I strengthened both my understanding of floating-point standards and my ability to architect complex digital designs.
Git Repository

title: Communication Network
text: Network diagram and explanatory slides later in page

title: Communication Network
text:
Impact Overview
While I was an intern, the team made a transition from working on the AUV to building an Autonomous boat from scratch. The ensuing business allowed me, as one of the two software engineers employed, to take ownership of the entire communication system between all of the company’s projects. A major consideration was to make operations wireless between the ground station and the vehicles. This came from the end goal of the entire system being long-distance and autonomous, which was not feasible with the previous tethered setup. The images and slides below will walk you through the communication network I built that has withstood the test of time. Even now, much of the networking and protocols I designed are still in place, even after my departure!

title: Communication Network
text:
What I owned



Network Design Had sole ownership of the decisions for how different system components communicated with each other.


Real Time Control Developed TCP/UDP servers and clients within FreeRTOS threads to manage low-latency communication between onboard systems.

text:
Networking Diagram

title: Lead-Free Brass Alloy (Award Winning Research)
text: First Place Research Poster at Bottom of Page Awarded by The Minerals, Metals, and Materials Society (TMS).

title: Lead-Free Brass Alloy (Award Winning Research)
text:
Impact Overview
I was recruited by Prof. Bassman at HMC to join her research team in Australia during the Summer to develop commercially viable lead-free brass alloys. The reason behind the focus on brass alloys was to provide a solution for the severe health impacts of lead contamination in drinking water that comes from brass pipes. I was one of three members of the experimental team that focused on alloy development and testing. I wore many hats on the team, but my two main ones were doing analysis on our alloys using the Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and doing alloy simulation using Thermo-Calc. The SEM allowed me to zoom so far in that I could see the microstructures of our alloys. From these SEM images, I conducted an analysis, which was the main source of information that steered the direction of further development. I used the Thermo-Calc software to predict what phases would occur in the microstructures for different alloy compositions without having to smelt the alloys, speeding up the testing cycle time. My contributions also spanned from competitor patent research to alloy smelting, to writing a research poster along with one other member of the team. The research poster we wrote resulted in us winning an international research award granted by the Minerals, Metals & Materials Society (TMS).

title: Lead-Free Brass Alloy (Award Winning Research)
text:
What I Owned



Microstructure Analysis Served as the sole Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) user to evaluate alloy compositions and guide iterative development.


Award-Winning Research Awarded first place at the 2025 international TMS Convention Student Research Poster Contest in the Structural Materials division.




Computational Metallurgy Utilized Thermo-Calc to predict phase compositions and simulate casting outcomes prior to physical fabrication.


Alloy Fabrication Fabricated alloys end-to-end from element-wise composition make-up, to smelting, to polishing.




Industry Viability Testing Performed metallurgical tests for hardness and ductility. Also performed machinability test, and hot rolling test to evaluate practicallity in industry.


Intellectual Property Research Conducted competitor analysis using USPTO databases to identify gaps in the market and guide novel alloy design.

title: Lead-Free Brass Alloy (Award Winning Research)
text: Analyzing Mircostructures on the SEM

title: Lead-Free Brass Alloy (Award Winning Research)

title: Welcome to Isaiah’s Portfolio
text: How to Navigate the Website: Either click the headings at the top that are sorted by company or scroll down on this page to and click on any of the grid entries that fancies you. Enjoy!

title: Welcome to Isaiah’s Portfolio
text:
About Isaiah
Isaiah Jeter is an embedded software engineer pursuing the value that Robotics and AI can have in industries where they haven’t previously been used. He has worked with embedded systems and computer vision to design autonomous robots. He is an Electrical Engineering major at Harvey Mudd College with a humanities emphasis in International Relations.

title: Welcome to Isaiah’s Portfolio
text: Engineering Showcase

title: FMA Hardware Project
text:
I designed and implemented a custom multicycle processor module in SystemVerilog capable of performing fused multiply-add operations on 16-bit half-precision floating-point numbers. I designed the unit in SystemVerilog, synthesized my iterations using Verilator. For testing, I wrote unit tests and analyzed register and variable signals over time. I also evaluated the hardware performance of FMA by generating area and timing reports, identifying the critical path, and computing the area–delay product to balance speed and efficiency.
This project challenged me to integrate multiple hardware concepts, including exponent alignment, mantissa normalization, and handling corner cases for addition and subtraction with differing exponents. I built supporting modules such as unpacking, product rounding, and shift/leading-zero detection logic, which all come together to execute floating-point arithmetic at the hardware level. By working through the details of rounding, overflow, and subtraction edge cases, I strengthened both my understanding of floating-point standards and my ability to architect complex digital designs.
Git Repository

title: Apple
text:
Impact Overview
Currently taking a novel approach to automating manufacturing processes for materials that have never been polished by a robot with micrometer level accuracy before. Developing code for a 6-axis robotic manufacturing arm as well as other technologies used in the solution.
More information pending NDA.

title: Subsea Simulation for AUV
text: I built a full PX4/ROS 2/Gazebo simulation environment for the company’s autonomous underwater vehicle, enabling automated test scenarios without the hardware needing to touch the water. By shifting trial-and-error into simulation, I accelerated the development cycle and reduced physical testing, which costs both money and time. My simulation’s accuracy was verified thorugh real worl testing which mirrored simulation results.

title: Subsea Simulation for AUV
text: I built a full PX4/ROS 2/Gazebo simulation environment for the company’s autonomous underwater vehicle, enabling automated test scenarios without the hardware needing to touch the water. By shifting trial-and-error into simulation, I accelerated the development cycle and reduced physical testing, which costs both money and time. My simulation’s accuracy was verified thorugh real worl testing which mirrored simulation results.

title: Subsea Simulation for AUV
text:
What I owned



Real-time Force Visualization Reports forces acting on individual AUV components as they happen.


High-Fidelity Physics Verified accurate buoyancy and interation physics with correctly modeled fins and motors.




Advanced Telemetry Interfaced with QGroundControl for telemetry to enable world position tracking.


Hardware Mirroring Equipped with the same sensor suite and sensor functionality as the physical AUV.




World and Model Development Built custom ocean world and 1:1 simulated AUV model.






Photo from simulation development

title: Amidon Heavy Industries
text: Click on any of the following four subsections to see their corresponding full page.

title: Amidon Heavy Industries
text:
Overview
Within weeks of starting at Amidon Heavy Industries, I was told that the systems I was building as an intern would be shipped on the company’s actual products. My work wasn’t just developing my skills, but directly shaping the future of the company’s technology. Following the completion of my first two projects, I began to be entrusted with mission-critical responsibilities ranging from developing firmware and drivers for STM32 microcontrollers, to building real-time TCP-based control systems in FreeRTOS, to implementing Wi-Fi video streaming pipelines. I made each prompt from my manager develop into a prototype, then into a production-ready technology, at the laser-fast times required at a startup. My reliability when it came to getting the job done fast established to my team both my technical ability and my capacity to adapt at startup speed.

title: Control System for AUV
text:
During primary testing of the AUV, the driver noted that the control algorithm in place was making it hard to generate lift with the fins (shown in video at the bottom of the page). The initial solution for this was alternating all of the fins by 45 degrees so that generating lift would be easier. After implementing this change, the team noticed that the old control system no longer worked for the new fin configurations. I took ownership of developing a new control system for the alternate fin configuration. This involved calculating inertia matrices, reading Fossen’s Marine Craft Hydrodynamics and Motor Control textbook, and writing new airframe files in the firmware. My control system’s accuracy was verified via an in-office test stand (shown below) and during the second in-water test of the AUV.



Picture of mini test stand used for fin configuration testing and servo testing

title: Control System for AUV
text:
During primary testing of the AUV, the driver noted that the control algorithm in place was making it hard to generate lift with the fins (shown in video at the bottom of the page). After implementing this change, the team noticed that the old control system no longer worked for the new fin configurations. I took ownership of developing a new control system for the alternate fin configuration. This involved calculating inertia matrices, reading Fossen’s Marine Craft Hydrodynamics and Motor Control textbook, and writing new airframe files in the firmware. My control system’s accuracy was verified via an in-office test stand (shown below) and during the second in-water test of the AUV.



Picture of mini test stand used for fin configuration testing and servo testing

title: Control System for AUV
text:
What I owned



Custom Airframe Firmware Made custom airframe file in the firmware that factored in the different torque, pitch, and roll allocation of each fin in the new fin configuration.


Steering Logic Implementation Programmed the core steering algorithms that interfaced directly with the vessel’s autonomous navigation stack.




Controlled Environemnt Testing Conducted out of water tests of new fimrware and control algorithms using mini test stand.

title: Control System for AUV
text:
Primary AUV Test



Video of the AUV failing to dive during primary testing

title: Multicycle Proccesor
text:
I built, simulated, and debugged a multicycle RISC-V processor in SystemVerilog. This was my first endeavor into RISC-V, and following this went to help the RISC-V research team from my school. While building this multicycle processor, I learned about pipelined processors, processor data paths, and processor memory.
Git Repository

title: Amazon Prime Air
text:
During takeoff in urban environments, Prime Air couldn’t accurately measure the location and orientation of its delivery drones (pictured below) due to electromagnetic interference from the surrounding buildings. I was on a team of six engineers tasked with solving these EMI-related localization failures. While researching non-GPS localization methods, I found AprilTags and introduced them to my team as a possible solution. We ended up going forward with them, and I led the sub-team developing them into our final solution.
During my time with Amazon Prime Air, I also worked on integrating sensors such as Lidar and cameras into the system. For the lidar, I worked with the subteam handling RFID sensors to integrate and tune sensor fusion pipelines combining RFID and LiDAR to improve robustness in state estimation. For the camera, I developed ROS nodes to enable real-time communication between perception systems and the flight controller.
The results of my work led to a trade study for Prime Air in which I wrote sections evaluating LiDAR- and vision-based localization approaches for aerial robotics. My work helped inform future navigation strategies for autonomous delivery platforms across the Prime Air platform.
